newsitem.title: PANAMA: Panama to clamp down on tuna fish violators.
newsitem.headline: Panama to clamp down on tuna fish violators.

text.p: Panama plans to clamp down harder on Panamanian-flagged ships caught violating tuna conservation efforts in order to avoid an international embargo, a top government official said Monday.

"Panama has done some work but we are going to establish more norms ... so that ships found not in compliance will be sanctioned with fines from $10,000 to $100,000 or have their registry taken away," Arnulfo Franco of Panama's National Maritime Commission told reporters.

Franco told reporters that Panamanian maritime officials told the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) last week in Spain that "we still don't have any evidence" that Panamanian-flagged ships are violating international tuna conservation efforts.
In a meeting in San Sebastian, Spain, the commission cleared the way for its members to ban imports of bluefin tuna from Belize, Honduras and Panama, which are not members.
The commission warned the three countries last year that fishing of the giant tuna on their ships was undermining efforts to save the fish.

ICCAT gave Panama, which has the world's largest registry of nearly 13,700 ships, up to Jan. 1, 1998, to show its measures are working before a ban would begin. Some eight percent of Panamanian-flagged ships are dedicated to fishing.
Most of the exports from the three countries go to Japan, which consumes up to 70 percent of the world's catch.
Japan imported a total of 674 metric tons of bluefin tuna from Belize, Panama and Honduras in 1994.
